awd_titl_txt: QuBBD: Estimating drug-drug and drug-disease interactions for nursing homes residents
awd_abstract_narration:
Drug-drug interaction (DDI) is a situation in which one drug affects the activity of another.  Drug-disease interaction (DDSI) is a situation where prescribed medication has the potential to exacerbate a preexisting disease.  Both DDI and DDSI are major causes of adverse drug effects (ADEs) and represent a considerable threat to public health.  Frail elderly patients have a higher prevalence of multiple morbidities and they are often prescribed a wide range of drugs to treat these morbidities.  Thus, they are at increased risk for adverse effects from DDI and DDSI.  Other than hospitalization, re-hospitalization and emergency room visits, little is known about the contribution of DDI and DDSI to other important outcomes, such as functional status, institutionalization, and mortality.  In addition, some DDIs and DDSIs are unknown and require evidence-based updates.  This award supports initiation of a collaborative research project with the long-term goal of developing methods that efficiently identify ADEs caused by DDIs and DDSIs by combining electronic health records with precise clinical data (such as gene sequencing).  These findings will enable the updating of current guidelines, generate alerts, identify possible chemical compounds that may interact and result in ADEs, and propose new genetic drug pathways.  The current objective, which is a step toward the long-term goal, is composed of two aims.  The first aim is to combine current methods in machine learning and statistical causal inference to accurately identify DDI and DDSI.  The second aim is to develop statistically valid methods that will impute missing patient level data in large detailed datasets. 

The project will exploit the availability of current datasets that could be augmented in the future to include precise clinical data.  The Minimum Data Set is part of the U.S. federally mandated process for clinical assessment of all residents in Medicare or Medicaid certified nursing homes.  It includes data on cognitive and functional abilities, disease diagnosis, psychological well-being, and medication use.  The dataset comprises millions of patients, thus enabling the discovery of DDIs and DDSIs that occur in a small fraction of the population.  The first aim comprises a combination of state-of-the-art supervised learning approaches such as LASSO, random forests, SVM, and Ensemble methods with efficient statistical causal inference approaches such as optimal matching, weighting, targeted learning, and multiple imputation.  The approach is innovative because it combines causal inference methods with supervised learning methods to generate accurate and precise methods that have statistically valid operating characteristics when providing estimates for a specific patient.  The second aim includes development of methods that rely on dimension reduction of the observed covariates to impute missing data.  When imputing missing data, the rule of thumb is to use all of the available data, so that the missing at random assumption (MAR) is plausible.  Dimension reduction aims to reduce the number of covariates that are used for prediction.  Thus, development of an imputation algorithm with many missing covariates requires striking a balance between dimension reduction and plausibility of the MAR assumption.  This award is supported by the National Institutes of Health Big Data to Knowledge (BD2K) Initiative in partnership with the National Science Foundation Division of Mathematical Sciences.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
This project aims were to develop statistical and computational methodologies to identify drugs that when administered together may result in adverse effects. This is a complex and involved problem, because adverse events are commonly rare and require large sample sizes to identify an effect. Moreover, randomized clinical trials commonly do not include patients who have multiple comorbidities and are on multiple medications. Thus, to identify drugs that may interact and cause adverse effects, researchers need to rely on observational studies. One possible source of observational data that can be used to identify effects of interaction between drugs is electronic medical records (EMR). However, EMR data may suffer from multiple complications. One possible complication is that data elements for some patients may be missing. This missingness can arise from certain lab results not being available for specific patients, some patients missing their appointments, and some patients change their providers. When the missingness is not related to outcome or baseline variables, statistical analyses would be less efficient but unbiased. Commonly, this is not the case, and there are observed variables that are correlated with the propensity for missingness. A possible solution to address missingness is to impute the missing values. When imputing missing data, it is important to account for errors that arise from not knowing the true values.  

We have developed an approach to multiply impute missing data by relying on a Bayesian matrix completion algorithm. This algorithm has several advantages over currently available multiple imputation algorithms. First, it propagates the errors that arise from missing data. Second, it assumes that a dataset that comprises of patients along the rows and their characteristics are the columns can be summarized using a low dimensional matrix. This allows for correlations among patients and addresses cases when the number of characteristics recorded for each patient is larger than the number of patients. In simulation analyses, we have shown that this method can result in smaller bias than current methods. Using the imputed data, researchers can use causal inference methods to estimate causal effects from observational studies without worrying about missing values.

As part of this project we also examined possible adverse effects of ovulation induction and ovarian stimulation pharmacologic interventions. Specifically, we considered the effects of these interventions on giving births to twins and higher order multiples. To examine this, we developed a Bayesian hierarchical model to estimate the natural rate of twins and higher order multiples in 1949-1967. These years predate the assisted reproduction era. Using this data, we identified the relationship between Mother’s age and race on the rates of twins and higher order multiples. These rates can then be used to address demographic changes that occurred in the age and race of mothers during the assisted reproduction era. Future work of ours will combine these modeling strategies with data from the Center for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) on in-vitro fertilization (IVF) to examine the unexplained rates of twin and higher order multiples that may be attributed to ovulation induction and ovarian stimulation pharmacologic interventions.

We will also continue to explore strategies to allow for causal inferences from drug-drug interactions using observational data.

 


Last Modified: 12/20/2021
Modified by: Roee Gutman
